module.title: Defensive Concepts
module.description: Master defensive formations, coverages, and strategies

lessons.title: Defensive Fronts
lessons.description: Learn the main defensive line formations and personnel packages

variant.prompt_richtext: What does '4-3 defense' mean?
variant.explanation_richtext: 4-3 defense has 4 defensive linemen (2 ends, 2 tackles) and 3 linebackers. It's a traditional, balanced defense good against both run and pass.

variant.prompt_richtext: What does '3-4 defense' mean?
variant.explanation_richtext: 3-4 defense has 3 defensive linemen (2 ends, 1 nose tackle) and 4 linebackers. It's versatile for blitzing and disguising pressure.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is nickel defense?
variant.explanation_richtext: Nickel defense has 5 DBs (the 5th DB is the 'nickel back'). It's used against 3+ WR sets, replacing a linebacker with an extra defensive back.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is dime defense?
variant.explanation_richtext: Dime defense has 6 DBs (dime = 10 cents = 2 nickels). It's used in obvious passing situations, typically with only 3 or 4 down linemen.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the primary job of defensive tackles in a 4-3?
options_json: Stop the run up the middle
variant.explanation_richtext: Defensive tackles line up over the guards and are primarily run-stoppers. They clog the middle and prevent inside running plays.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the primary job of defensive ends?
options_json: Rush the passer and set the edge on runs
variant.explanation_richtext: Defensive ends rush the QB on passes and 'set the edge' on runs (prevent outside runs). They're typically the best pass rushers on the defense.

variant.prompt_richtext: In a 3-4 defense, where does the nose tackle line up?
variant.explanation_richtext: The nose tackle lines up directly over the center (on their 'nose'). They're usually the biggest player on defense and anchor the middle.

variant.prompt_richtext: What's a key difference between 4-3 and 3-4 defenses?
variant.explanation_richtext: 3-4 defenses have 4 linebackers, creating more blitz options and disguise. The offense doesn't know which LBs will rush. 4-3 is more straightforward.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a team's 'base defense'?
variant.explanation_richtext: Base defense is a team's standard formation - either 4-3 or 3-4. Teams build their entire defensive system around their base front.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why do defenses use nickel and dime packages?
options_json: To match speed when offense uses multiple WRs
variant.explanation_richtext: When offenses use 3+ WRs, defenses need more DBs to match speed. Nickel and dime packages replace slower LBs with faster defensive backs.

lessons.title: Cover 1 Defense
lessons.description: Learn man-free coverage and its strengths and weaknesses

variant.prompt_richtext: What is Cover 1 defense?
variant.explanation_richtext: Cover 1 (or 'man-free') has defenders play man-to-man coverage on receivers with 1 deep safety providing help over the top.

variant.prompt_richtext: In Cover 1, what is the free safety's job?
options_json: Provide deep help and prevent big plays
variant.explanation_richtext: The free safety in Cover 1 plays deep middle and helps on any deep routes. They're the last line of defense and prevent touchdowns.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a strength of Cover 1?
variant.explanation_richtext: Since only 1 safety plays deep, Cover 1 allows 6+ defenders to rush or play near the line. This creates pressure and stops the run.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a weakness of Cover 1?
options_json: Vulnerable to pick routes and rub concepts
variant.explanation_richtext: Man coverage struggles against pick/rub routes where receivers cross and create natural interference. The free safety can't help everywhere.

variant.prompt_richtext: In man coverage, what should a defender focus on?
variant.explanation_richtext: In man coverage, defenders watch the receiver's hips (which don't lie) and mirror their movements. Looking at the QB or ball causes you to lose position.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is 'press' coverage in Cover 1?
options_json: Defender lines up close and jams receiver at the line
variant.explanation_richtext: Press coverage has the defender line up close to the receiver and 'jam' them at the line to disrupt their route. It's aggressive man coverage.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is 'off' coverage?
options_json: Defender plays 5-10 yards off the receiver
variant.explanation_richtext: Off coverage has the defender give a cushion (5-10 yards) to the receiver. This prevents getting beat deep but allows short completions.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is 'Cover 1 Robber'?
options_json: Free safety plays shallow to rob crossing routes
variant.explanation_richtext: Cover 1 Robber has the free safety play shallow to 'rob' crossing routes and underneath passes instead of playing deep. A linebacker may play deep instead.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why do offenses love mismatches in man coverage?
options_json: Fast WR vs slow LB creates easy completions
variant.explanation_richtext: In man coverage, if a fast receiver is matched against a slower linebacker, the receiver has a huge advantage. Offenses exploit these mismatches.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why is Cover 1 often paired with blitzes?
options_json: Only need 1 deep safety, freeing up rushers
variant.explanation_richtext: Cover 1 only requires 1 deep safety, so more defenders can blitz or play near the line. This creates pressure while maintaining deep coverage.

lessons.title: Cover 2 Defense
lessons.description: Learn two-deep zone coverage and its variations

variant.prompt_richtext: What is Cover 2 defense?
options_json: 2 deep safeties split the field in half
variant.explanation_richtext: Cover 2 has two safeties each responsible for half the deep field. Underneath defenders play zone coverage. It's a balanced zone defense.

variant.prompt_richtext: In Cover 2, what area do the safeties cover?
variant.explanation_richtext: Each safety covers a deep half (left or right). They prevent deep passes down the sidelines and over the top. Everything underneath is zone coverage.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a strength of Cover 2?
variant.explanation_richtext: Cover 2 safeties take away deep sideline routes (9 routes, corners). The defense can also get 8 defenders near the line to stop the run.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a weakness of Cover 2?
options_json: Vulnerable to deep middle passes (seam routes)
variant.explanation_richtext: The seam between the two safeties (deep middle) is vulnerable in Cover 2. Tight ends and slot receivers can exploit this area with seam routes.

variant.prompt_richtext: In Cover 2, who covers the 'flats' (near the sideline)?
variant.explanation_richtext: In Cover 2, corners play the flats (short areas near the sideline) instead of deep coverage. They must stop quick outs and screens.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is 'Tampa 2' coverage?
options_json: Cover 2 with MLB dropping deep to cover the seam
variant.explanation_richtext: Tampa 2 is Cover 2 where the middle linebacker drops deep to cover the seam between safeties. This fixes Cover 2's main weakness but requires athletic LBs.

variant.prompt_richtext: How many zones are there in Cover 2?
variant.explanation_richtext: Cover 2 typically has 5 underneath zones (2 flats, 2 hooks/curls, 1 middle) and 2 deep zones. Seven defenders drop into coverage.

variant.prompt_richtext: What route concept beats Cover 2?
variant.explanation_richtext: Four vertical routes stretch the 2 safeties horizontally. They can't cover 4 deep routes, creating holes in coverage. This is a classic Cover 2 beater.

variant.prompt_richtext: Is Cover 2 good against the run?
options_json: Yes, can get 8 defenders in the box
variant.explanation_richtext: Cover 2 can be excellent against the run. With only 2 deep safeties, you can have 9 defenders near the line (4 DL, 3 LB, 2 CB). This stops runs.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is 'Cover 2 Sink'?
options_json: Corners sink deeper to help with intermediate routes
variant.explanation_richtext: Cover 2 Sink has corners play deeper (8-12 yards) to help with intermediate routes and take away the seam. It's a variation that trades flats for better middle coverage.

lessons.title: Cover 3 Defense
lessons.description: Learn three-deep zone coverage and its applications

variant.prompt_richtext: What is Cover 3 defense?
options_json: 3 deep defenders each cover 1/3 of the field
variant.explanation_richtext: Cover 3 has three defenders (2 corners and 1 safety) each covering a deep third of the field. It's a zone coverage that's strong against deep passes.

variant.prompt_richtext: In Cover 3, which defenders play deep?
options_json: Both corners and the free safety
variant.explanation_richtext: In Cover 3, both corners drop deep to cover the outside thirds while the free safety covers the middle third. The strong safety plays underneath.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a strength of Cover 3?
options_json: Strong against deep passes and vertical routes
variant.explanation_richtext: Cover 3 has three deep defenders, making it very strong against deep passes. Vertical routes are well-covered with defenders in each third.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a weakness of Cover 3?
options_json: Vulnerable to flat routes and quick outs
variant.explanation_richtext: With corners playing deep, the flats (short sideline areas) are vulnerable in Cover 3. Quick outs, screens, and flat routes can exploit this.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is 'Cover 3 Buzz'?
options_json: Strong safety replaces corner in the flat
variant.explanation_richtext: Cover 3 Buzz has the strong safety 'buzz' to the flat to replace the corner, allowing the corner to play deeper. This helps defend both deep and flat routes.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is 'Cover 3 Cloud'?
options_json: Corner plays flat, safety rotates to deep third
variant.explanation_richtext: Cover 3 Cloud has the corner play the flat while the safety rotates over to cover the deep third. This is better against quick passes but can be vulnerable deep.

variant.prompt_richtext: How many zones are in Cover 3?
variant.explanation_richtext: Cover 3 has 3 deep zones (thirds) and typically 4 underneath zones (2 flats, 2 hooks). Seven defenders drop into coverage.

variant.prompt_richtext: What route concept beats Cover 3?
options_json: Flood concept (3 receivers to one side)
variant.explanation_richtext: Flood concepts (3 receivers at different depths on one side) overload Cover 3. The corner has to choose between deep, intermediate, or flat - someone gets open.

variant.prompt_richtext: How does Cover 3 defend the run?
options_json: Strong safety and linebackers fill gaps
variant.explanation_richtext: In Cover 3, the strong safety plays near the line and fills run gaps with linebackers. With corners deep, you have 8 defenders for the run.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is 'Sky' coverage in Cover 3?
options_json: Safety takes deep outside third, corner plays flat
variant.explanation_richtext: Sky coverage (opposite of Cloud) has the safety take the deep outside third while the corner plays the flat. This is used to the strong side of formations.

lessons.title: Cover 4 Defense
lessons.description: Learn quarters coverage and pattern matching concepts

variant.prompt_richtext: What is Cover 4 defense?
options_json: 4 deep defenders each cover 1/4 of the field
variant.explanation_richtext: Cover 4 (or 'Quarters') has 4 deep defenders - 2 corners and 2 safeties - each responsible for a quarter of the deep field.

variant.prompt_richtext: In Cover 4, which defenders play deep?
variant.explanation_richtext: Cover 4 has both corners and both safeties playing deep, each covering a quarter. This creates maximum deep coverage with 4 deep defenders.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a strength of Cover 4?
options_json: Excellent against deep passes and 4 verticals
variant.explanation_richtext: Cover 4 is the best coverage against 4 vertical routes because you have 4 deep defenders. Each can match a vertical receiver man-to-man.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is a weakness of Cover 4?
variant.explanation_richtext: With 4 defenders deep, only 3 linebackers cover underneath. Crossing routes and intermediate passes can find holes between the levels.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is 'pattern matching' in Cover 4?
options_json: Defenders match receivers based on route patterns
variant.explanation_richtext: Pattern matching has defenders start in zone but match receivers man-to-man based on their routes. If a receiver goes vertical, the defender matches them.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is the '2-read' in Cover 4?
options_json: Defender reads #2 receiver to determine coverage
variant.explanation_richtext: In Cover 4, defenders read the #2 receiver (slot/TE). If #2 goes vertical, the safety matches them. If #2 stays short, the safety helps on #1 deep.

variant.prompt_richtext: Why is Cover 4 good against 2x2 formations?
variant.explanation_richtext: Against 2x2 (2 receivers each side), Cover 4 has perfect balance - 2 deep defenders on each side. Each side can play 2-man coverage on the receivers.

variant.prompt_richtext: What is 'Cover 4 Palms'?
variant.explanation_richtext: Cover 4 Palms is a specific pattern-matching scheme with detailed rules for how defenders match routes. It's a hybrid of man and zone coverage.

variant.prompt_richtext: How does Cover 4 defend trips (3 receivers to one side)?
options_json: Rotates coverage to get 3 defenders to that side
variant.explanation_richtext: Against trips, Cover 4 typically rotates to get 3 defenders (corner, safety, and a linebacker) to the trips side. The backside plays Cover 3 or man.

variant.prompt_richtext: What's the main difference between Cover 4 and Cover 2?
options_json: Cover 4 has 4 deep, Cover 2 has 2 deep
variant.explanation_richtext: Cover 4 splits the deep field into quarters (4 defenders), while Cover 2 splits it into halves (2 defenders). Cover 4 is better against deep passes.
